Tom -- most of what you say is engaging in the argument that "all scientists are stupid and I know the truth, and they are stupid and lying." The parts that aren't are classic Freud "bucket joke" material -- i.e. "Alaska people want warmer weather?"

Every one of your questions about weather and climate is one that has been extensively studied by the scientific community. The issue of hurricane frequencies and intensity is a matter of current vigorous research and scientific argument -- for a lay perspective see here:

http://science.time.com/2013/09/09/a-silent-hurricane-season-ignites-a-d...

Saying "crickets, etc" is just parroting the wattsup blogosphere.

Your "bucket joke" is simultaneously claiming that AGW isn't real … but hey, if it is … that's a good thing. The only part of the joke you left out is "I never borrowed your bucket in the first place" … which is rather hard to do in this context.

And then as far as "Alaska sea levels falling" … you mean "GULF of Alaska…" look here:

http://www.adn.com/article/southern-alaskan-sea-levels-defy-worldwide-tr...

You do whatever "cause" it is that you seem to espouse no good by parroting ignorance.

David Bensen is correct that Vermont Yankee shut down because it couldn't compete with natural gas burners … but this is rather sad and telling about the state of economics for nuclear power in the US -- Vermont Yankee is an old nuclear plant, it ought to be "fully amortized" … and if it were any other sort of power producer one might imagine it being far more economic to continue than (for instance) building new nuclear plant(s) … or wind or solar.

But the problem is precisely that Vermont Yankee faced large and uncertain costs about maintenance and safety and license extension … and in the face of low-cost natural gas power for "as far as the eye can see" -- no further investment is prudent, time to quit.

The interesting question is the degree to which cheap NG in the US shuts everything else down … and for how long.

Three points. First there is no clear scientific evidence, and no scientific consensus (as opposed to what one hears in the popular press) that climate change is producing more frequent hurricanes.
Second, falling sea-level in the Arctic and in Scandinavia is due to post-glacial rebound - that is, the land is very slowly recovering from being depressed by the ice sheets of the last ice age. It has absolutely nothing to do with anthropogenic climate change.
As for the hiatus, while warming seems to have slowed over the last couple of years it hasn't stopped. The last 10 years were the warmest on record and 2014 is on track to be the warmest year on record.
